content.description:
Is this problem good or bad? Hard to say...but it sure is amusing. Start on the far left side of the face on thin holds and pull onto the wall. Traverse right until you can reach the lip.

May involve a crux foot deadpoint.
content.location: Left of Proprioception.

content.description:
Shuffle up a little mini chimey into a hand crack that widens to offwidth near the top.

"Stink Bug" To grab a skateboard rail between your legs with your butt sticking out resembling a Stinkbug. How I looked climbing the lower section of this route.
content.location: Below Raven's Choice, requires some bushwhacking. 33.03533869692003, -116.99827233902143

content.description: Another fun friction slab with cool features. Step up into the good rail feature, high step right to the next, then friction topout on the right side. A direct finish straight up the prow may be possible and harder.
content.location: Just north of the Summit Towers, in the gully between the Towers and the North Ridge.

content.description:
Start with a good foot rail and step onto small feet to reach the “good” holds. One powerful move leads to easier but sustained slab above.

(Stay right of the higher start on the left.. that's an easier slab)
content.location:
33.0336 x -116.9987

(Next to Poop Deck)

Downclimb then jump to adjacent boulder and chimney to the bottom.

content.description:
This is a clean thin crack starting off a jagged block. Tips to fingers. The rock quality is excellent.

There are a couple ravens that rule this hill with casual authority. Despite nearby suburban development, it's hard not to feel like a guest in their realm when visiting this spot.

Video:

youtu.be/0dIpn7y-Fg0
content.protection: A couple finger-sized pieces for the lead. Up to 1.5" for anchor.
content.location: 100 yards north of the "Two Towers," a gigantic boulder, the biggest in the area, sits on a ridge.  The climb is another 100 yards NNE of the gigantic boulder.  It faces north but the crack is visible from above.

content.description:
On one of the most unique looking boulders I've seen, the line climbs straight up the center of the face of this cleavage plane. The moves from start to finish are desperate and require some tricky balance and footwork, hence the name.

Variation: Thumb Up My Ass ~V6: Off route the crimps to the right of the starting holds and go straight up with a deceptively difficult mantle.

This tall slab only allows an unassuming series of moves to claw your way through the crux to the easier top-out.  Bearing a striking resemblance to the aft of a ship, this boulder problem has earned my respect.  Downclimb via chimney between boulders.
Sit start and climb a wide hand/fist crack formed by two boulders leaning together, followed by easy chimneying to the top.
content.location: East facing boulders 30 yards west of Ravens' Choice.

content.description:
Start matched on a cool, jug edge on the left side of the overhang. Power up to a good sloper and top out. Awesome rock.

The easy slab to the right is also fun.
content.location:
33.034335, -116.999116

Directly downhill from the North Slope Monolith.

content.description: Same start as Heat Cramps then work up and left using a right hand/heel match then a series of difficult bumps on small holds. Crux is establishing feet after the overhang.
content.location: Reference Heat Cramps

content.description: Start high on the overhang and dyno to the shelf above. Crux is moving feet up and not peeling off the sloper.
content.location:
Look for the boulder with a wide S crack. Once you find that, look to the right (East) and you’ll see a boulder with thin, paralleling cracks. That’s your target.

33.0336, -116.9976

content.description:
Start with positive holds within the crack of the egg and walk your feet up to a good left foot. From here, find a way to the easier crack to the left. Rock quality is very good.

I down-climbed Cow's Choice 5.8
content.location: Directly east of Ravens Choice.

content.description: Start matched on a small crimp sidepull with bad feet. Pull on and fire up to a small crimp, jump to a juggy edge, and topout on good holds.
content.location: On the backside of the big slab boulder seen north from the Summit Towers

content.description: Clean face on great rock, with a cool mantle start. I chose to start with the mantle, though starting around the corner on a jug is possible too. After the first move, follow cool holds up the nice face.
content.location: Just west of Ravens' Choice. Obvious big slab.

content.description: Vertical face with good edges starts out down in a narrow gap between boulders.  Good quality problem.

Sit start with a left sidepull and right gaston and make a few powerful moves on cool holds to a good horizontal edge. Finish up the arete. A great crimp problem on cool rock!

The right side of the arete is V1 from a stand start.
content.location: By the water tower on the west end of the north slope. Expect some bushwhacking.

content.description: A short left-leaning hand crack passing through a pod.
content.protection: Jump off the south side of the boulder or downclimb the crack to descend.
content.location: Just east of Ravens' Choice.

content.description: Cool feature! Mantle into the scoop, then make a foot traverse up and left to top out.
content.location: By the water tower on the west end of the North Slope.

climbs.name: Bish Bobbish
climbs.fa: Jed Jirak, Ben May, Aden Parker

content.description: Start on the lowest, good slopers, and traverse left on more slopers finishing with a big move to a jug. High step and top out the slab. Fun stuff!
content.location: Uphill from Ravens' Choice.

content.description: Low start below thick brush then into a thin, left leaning tips crack.  Easy topout.
content.location:
33.0351 x -116.9991

Just NE of the water tank
